Anyways.  Love this pizza.  The crust is tender.  There is nothing like a freshly baked, well made pizza.  The cheese here was a veritable SLICK of dense salty cheese.  The dough was thin but it held up against the tomato sauce.  I got a slice of cheese.  Or was it two slices?  

My heart smiled when the cheese stretched out as I pulled the slice free of the pie.  Coaxing the loving morsel on to my paper plate before I ravaged it with unspeakable desires wrought by my teeth.  That's right.  I'm writing in the manner of paperback trash novels, and in that tightly bodiced velvet dress spilling out over the satin folds is a supple slice of pizza.
author: Christina C.

description:
It's your run-of-the-mill Pizza, nothing special. The Fiancial District location has a great lunch special--2 slices of Pepperoni & a small soda for just $5.95. I have also eaten the Pesto Pizza before...it's good but no Pizza Orgasmica. Also, they have a $2 beer special after 3pm which is worth taking advantage of.

They have a good ambiance, playing Air when I most recently visited for lunch.

If you're in a pinch for time and/or money, this is a quick fix.
author: matt m.

description:
$3.90 for the pesto-potato pizza. With all the rave reviews on Yelp, I expected it to rock my socks off. It was good, but I could have used some more of that garlic. The pesto flavor was great.

It was particularly cold today, so a heated pizza really warmed the soul (as much as pizza can, at least). The prices are somewhat high, but they accept credit cards!

I'm not an expert on New York pizza, but I'm more than sure that this isn't it. My slice had the same cracker-crust crunch as some of the other take-out pizzerias in SF.  I was really looking forward to a foldable, melty pizza.

The seating in the Fin Dist is nice. It's sort of a nook on the side where you can sit and watch people walk by. I was doing a quick bite-and-go, and I didn't feel uncomfortable eating there by myself.
author: Keane L.

description:
Exiled from New York:

Not bad, but a sad excuse for NY style pizza.  In fact, the best things offered at Escape From New York are pretty damn "California Style."  Case in point: the potato, garlic and pesto pizza is relatively tasty.  

Nonetheless, fairly uninspired.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Seeing the name of the establishment outside I immediately thought of the old movie starring Kurt Russell as Snake Plissken.  Predictably I find similarities between the movie and this pizza place; described below:

*  Cheap
*  A tad bit over-the top (especially the tomato sauce for the pizza)
*  Not that good
*  Tired and old looking (especially under that heat lamp for who knows how long).
*  During the middle thinking, "man this sucks."
*  Regretted spending my money on it
*  Disappointed after finishing it

In the movie they made a sequel.  For the pizza there are other locations around SF.  Thanks but I think I'll pass on both.
author: Bill P.

description:
Sooo good!

I had the sausage, green pepper, and red onion pizza.  It was fresh from the oven and absolutely delicious.  It was like $4.  So cheesy, big, and greasy.....yum

Several people said the pizza was old and microwaved.  I didnt even see a microwave in the shop.  They did heat some slices in the oven; but every pizza shop does that.  Wait for a fresh slice like I did.

Only bummer is that I didnt find this place sooner!
author: Sherill M.

description:
DELICIOUS.

Came here while I was visiting my brother at work and I gotta say, it was pretty darn good. I got a slice of the Glorious Chicken that had very fresh garlic and spinach. *Warning: if you don't like the taste, smell, feel of garlic, stay away! The slices were huge and it definitely filled me up. 

Brother got slices of the Big Applewood Chicken & Big Meat Combo. WIN, WIN! The Applewood chicken had just the right amount of BBQ sauce so that it's not overpowering the chicken or cheese. Meat Combo was alright but that's only because I'm not a big meat eater. 

The dining area was very comfortable and clean. A nice atmosphere to sit down and grab some lunch. 

Our total came out to be around $13 or so. Not bad for the crispy, crunchy deliciousness that went into my mouth. Now only if they migrated to Dallas, Tx..

**Side note: They had a deal on Tuesdays for the month of July where you could get any slice of pizza for $2! A little late now but look out for more specials in the future!
author: Gwan C.

description:
If I suddenly found myself in a situation that forced me to escape from New York and I could only bring three things with me, one of them would surely be pizza. (followed closely by the Mac&Cheese from Cafeteria and the corn from Cafe Habana).

Reality is, there is no other city that serves up a better pie! And that leads me to ponder the semantics of this restaurant's name. Is it "Escape from New York :::pause::: Pizza" [as in you are escaping from the city?] or is it "Escape from  New york Pizza" ? In alignment with my previous thoughts about the greatness of it, I cannot imagine that the latter would be the correct phrase. Like, why would anyone want to escape from the yum that is New York pizza. That's like naming a restaurant Good Riddance to Maine Lobster.

In any event, I should have known better. You can't just stick the words "pizza" and "New York" in the same sentence (or in this case phrase) and hope to replicate the very essence that makes pies from the Big Apple so damn delectable.

You can be good. You can certainly have better, more efficient and polite service standards. Your delivery can be faster. You can even trump the East Coast on value. But quality, taste, flavor? It's a tough sell.
author: Leighann F.

description:
Escape is like my second home. 

My friends are always coming here after school for the happy hour deals. A slice of cheese or pepperoni for only $2.50? Cha-ching. Buy 7 slices and get 1 slice free? Cha-ching. Bring one of those coupons off the menu that are buy one slice get one free? Cha-ching. Show up near closing so they give you free pizza so it doesn't go to waste? Cha-ching. A large soda at a reasonable price with free refills? Oh, the deals here are insane. 

This place is best from 4 to 6 where it's frequently empty and the happy hour special are in full spring. The place looks great, is always clean, and the music they have on in the background is usually some nice soothing soft rock. It's a nice mellow place to just crash with friends, talk about life, and play a few rounds of cards. 

If you come during the lunch rush the place is much less fun. It's crowded, loud, and the prices aren't the same great deal they are during happy hour. To fully enjoy this place you have to come later for the more personal pizza service.

Staff is friendly and agreeable, there is always plenty of pizza condiments to go around. I've never gone there and been unable to get to the pepper, garlic powder, or parmesan that I so needed.   

Escape gets a perfect 5/5 Stars for having a great staff, perfect atmosphere, incredible deals, and the most delicious pizza in the city.
author: Robert P.

description:
Last Monday at 5:15 pm I found myself wandering the streets of our beautiful Financial District looking for some food.  Don't worry, I am not the guy holding the door for you at McDonald's hoping for a handout.  I had just come back from a long a trip, and I needed to grab a quick bite before teaching my 6 pm class.  

Apparently, every establishment in the area closes early.  The halls of Crocker Galleria were empty.  I was running out of time and out of options.  Just when I thought I had to settle for a McDonald's Quarter Pounder with Cheese, i saw the light.  Literally.  I saw the light inside Escape From New York, which was my only indication that the place was actually open.  There were no customers inside, and the only cashier was almost hiding behind the counter.

I walked in and ordered 2 slices of what appeared to be Big Meat Combo.  The girl at the counter, visibly unhappy with all this extra work she had to do, put 2 giants slices in the oven for reheating.  I also got a small fountain soda, which meant that I was out about $10.  Boy, since when do 2 slices of pizza and a small soda cost you ten dollars?  Ouch!

While waiting for my pizza to be reheated, I looked around.  The place didn't remind me of New York, but it sure did remind me of a place I wanted to escape.  The only difference between the decor at this location and the decor of your local Panda Express was the abundance of old movie posters and abstract renderings of the Manhattan skyline.

The pizza itself was "New York" in name only.  It was a big, greasy slice of thin crust pizza and sub-par toppings.  The sausage wasn't very good, the rest of the toppings were OK.  Even when covered with crush red peppers and grated Parmesan, the pizza wasn't the best.  It just didn't have that kick of flavor one would expect in a New York style pizza.

The place gets a few bonus points for being open long after the lunch rush and major bonus points for cleanliness.  The place was absolutely spotless, a definite plus for a pizza establishment.
author: Yan G.

description:
Good deals on pizza, salad and a soda. Around $7 bucks for all three depending on the kind of pizza you get.  

I like people watching on Bush St from their counter seats.
author: Elsa E.

description:
I love the plaza at 333 bush. Aside from the outdoor seating, you walk up there, and BAM! Pizza! Turn a little to the left and there's a burger place! And what's that behind you? Hot Dogs! You're surrounded by all the grease and sodium that you know you're craving. Give in!

There's a reason this alley was named Trinity St.

This particular EfNY location has the same stuff by the slice as the other locations (The veggie one with feta and artichoke hearts, the potato & garlic, the sliced sausage & pepperoni) and they move customers through there pretty quickly. Also, they stay open throughout the afternoon while every place else closes early, so when your blood sugar levels are tanking at 4:30 PM they're there for you. These things combined are worth four stars or so.
author: matthew r.

description: Not bad.  Slice of any variety, small salad and coke will run you $6.46 all in.  They had a good assortment of toppings to choose from and the meat on mine seemed of good quality.  I didn't care for the fact that the cheese and sauce ended too far from the end of the crust, though.  I went a little late so they had to reheat the slice but it was still ok.  The place didn't wow me, especially for the price, but when in the mood for a quick slice, I'd go again.  Salad was pretty nice and Newman's Own Balsamic dressing was very good.  Some New York stuff on the wall like old Yankees photos. They need more memrobilia from the movie Escape from New York, one of my favorites.  A big poster of Snake Plissken with eye-patch would up the rating one star for me.
author: Marc S.

description:
I like this place more because of the surrounding area than just the food-- a small florist, a place that carries photos and big prints, the little "plaza" area in the alley, my kind of lunch place.

Food wise, I had the mini-combo which includes a slice of pizza (I had chicken with spinach), small salad, and a small drink-- the right portion for a lunch, something that you won't fall asleep 2 hours afterwards...
author: T L.

description: Yes it is an Escape but something was missing... Does bohemian atmosphere have a flavor?  Crust not as crunchy?  I really can't put my finger on it - perhaps the crust was less done than the other EFNYPs.  This location has beer and wine and ample indoor and outdoor seating.  $2.88 for a cheese slice.
author: Jeff J.

description: I've been ordering pies from here for a few years for the various seminars I teach downtown and for Beats for Boobs, an annual breast cancer awareness fundraiser. The pizza's great  and the service is friendly and efficient. The manager, Mike is such a great guy. He's gone above and beyond my expectations of customer service. He's been extremely generous with donating pizzas for our events and even delivers them to our venue on his own time after the restaurant is closed. The pizzas are so good too, with lots of unique choices to choose from! I'll definitely keep ordering from them for my classes and would enjoy continuing to work with them for future fundraising events too! Thanks! You guys are awesome!
author: Jen G.

description: Our members at Planet Fitness get free pizza the first Monday of every month and they request Escape every time. There pesto pizza is my favorite.
author: Stella R.

description:
This is a good quick fix when you need to eat something doughy... Don't expect gourmet now... it is just pizza by the slice and for what it is... it is good.  If you want something fancier... then you might want to try a sit down type restaurant. If you feel the guilties... you can have a salad with your pizza... but you know you are just adding even more calories with the dressing... that's ok though... I won't tell! Have your pizza and eat it too!!!! LOL

Another plus is that they stay open late in comparison to other FiDi outlets. Bless your souls for that!
author: Amelia M.

description:
The cheese-deal for $5.37 (2 slices of cheese and a soda) is a good deal for lunch.. otherwise, the only real standout slice for me is the chicken parmesean.  Haven't had their sandwiches, and their salads are kinda pricey for what they are.  

Depending on who you have at the counter, you might get a huge slice, or a mediocre slice.  I don't exactly understand why they ask for tips when they're simply handing you a slice of pizza.. their attitude seems to be affected by how much you drop in the milk jug or write on your receipt.
author: Tristan G.

description: Was in the lunchroom and saw empty boxes from this place.  The menu looked interested.  Ventured out today.  I normally hit SOMA places.  Nice walk to Bush Street.  Quick and easy.  Excellent selection of pies.  I had the mushroom and pesto/roasted garlic/red potato slices.  Good flavors and excellent crust.  Will definitely be back.
author: Josh L.

description:
Okay, okay.  Definately not the best pizza in the city, but one of my favorite joints to go hang out.  I come here with my friends (Robert P. being one of them) after school like thrice a week.  

The menu offers a huge variety of slices with a whole assortment of toppings.  From anchovies to zucchini/vegetarian to roast chicken to pesto to pineapple to applewood to Canadian bacon and everything in between, Escape has it all.  The slices are relatively large for the price (about 2.75 for the pepperoni).  Different slices vary in price (3.50 for the Meat Combo Supreme).  Lots of cheese shakers and herb and spice dispensers lying around you can help yourself to.  Good pizza, free water, lots of seating (outdoor included), warm and cozy atmosphere, music that's easy on the ears, and friendly service makes this one of my favorite joints to chill out at with my friends.

Great place to go during or after those downtown shopping runs.

Only thing that ticks me off is that the place closes too soon, around 5:45 pm on weekdays.
author: Alan H.

description: Had a slice of combination from here today.  I've probably walked by here a hundred times, so figured I'd stop by.  The pizza was alright and the prices fair for the area.  It was nothing amazing, but it did the trick.  The toppings were fresh.  The cheese was good (though it could have used a little more).  The service was fine.  It wasn't busy and they took care of everything very quickly.  I'll go back if I want a quick slice close to the office.
author: Brian G.

description:
Best place to grab a cheap slice in the financial district/nob hill area? Oh hell yes!

EFNY (to abbreviate) is easily my favorite pizza in all of SF at this point in time. It's good. No, I mean REALLY good. The pesto/potato/roasted garlic pizza is just mind-blowingly delicious, if you can get over the fact that they were crazy enough to put freaking potatoes on pizza. The gourmet (spinach/artichoke/feta/tomatoes) is quite amazing as well, put the two together for one hell of a killer pizza combo. Free WiFi is also a killer bonus for this place, but not many people know about that.
author: Thom B.

description: The pizza here is not whats its worked up to be.........Ive been to this place on several occasion just in the pizza mood.......Can we say the people here are SO FREAKIN RUDE...........I dont understand them at all....If you want bad pizza along with poor attitude check this place out.........
author: Nelly S.

description:
I can only really base my opinion on the pesto and pepperoni slices.

Yup. 4 stars EASY! They have quality pesto. Very nice, good taste to it, that's not overporing like at some other places. The crust and bread are really god with a semi-crunchy, still soft kinda bread which i think is perfect!

WOW@ Matthew P!

We get catered too! ANd we order to much food as well too! HAHAH..

wow. small world?
author: Elijah W.

description:
I escaped from NY too, and I like the pizza here.  Just a simple, straightforward, no-frills slice of cheese pizza does the trick for me.   The salads aren't bad, either.  And the kids at the Financial District site are all nice, and they don't call me ma'am.  Extra star for that.

However, I'm knocking one star off because I believe that no slice of cheese pizza should ever cost more than the current price of a single New York subway fare ($2).
author: DD B.

description: I must have had the "You Say Potato" over 25 times this year as I've been through 3 or 4 of those cards.  It's always quick and the people are nice.
author: Jack M.

description:
it's Called "Escape from New York" because they were run out of the Real New York. The New York City Pizzaria Association got together with their torches and effigies and told these guys "Youse bettah get the f*ck outta town mit your high prices and your sh*tty sauce!!" 

So the owners set up shop in SF -- where the dumb Californians don't know any better. It hurt me to spend $2.62 for a slice of cheese pizza: HURT ME!!! And it wasn't that great. :( :(

But, it was nice to get some cheese pizza -- no matter the level.
author: Molly E.

description:
Free drinks all night at the Shanti Volunteer Appreciation Gala + no real food in my tummy for hours = I am very drunk and need to eat pizza NOW dammit.

My BF and I ordered the vegetarian special, he lives downtown so delivery was fast. The pizza was quite delicious. Good crispy crust (on the outside of the pie anyway), nice meaty olives, just the right mix of tomato sauce to cheese. Being that I woke up this morning with only a mild hangover, I salute you, Escape From New York Pizza.

Minus a star for crust being slightly soggy in the middle. 

Minus another star because pizza is my favorite food on the planet, and it takes a lot to impress me. You have to work for it. I need to see some sweat, people.
author: Angie R.

description:
Just got back from my first lunch here.  Let's see...

Cool decor and plenty of seating as well as seating in a nice courtyard outside with shielding on 3 sides from sun and streets.

Employees were  passable.  Not quite rude, not very professional, but fast with the pizza and they got the job done.  They seemed to be staffed for a lot more customers, but I arrived at 12:05 and there were about 6 people working behind the counter, mostly doing nothing.

The pizza itself is probably an 8 out of 10 by SF standards and a 5 out of 10 by national standards (I am from Washington, DC which has good NY pizza but isn't NY).  Crispy crust, chewy inside.  A little too thick for NY pizza and the sauce is a little too sweet and a little too thick.  Cheese and toppings (I had pepperoni) were totally good.

Would be nice to see hot sauce on the condiment stand.  Will likely be back as there is very little opportunity for pizza by the slice downtown, let alone halfway decent pizza by the slice.
author: Lauren J.

description:
My fellow New York escapees here in San Francisco will probably agree that this isn't the best NY slice ever.  No, no.  For me that distinction goes to Umberto's or Bleecker St. Pizza in NY.

I will say, though, that Escape From New York Pizza makes the best New York style slice in San Francisco.  It's got all the hallmarks of a real NY pizza joint: the glass case with a dozen different pizzas sold by the slice, doughy, saucy slices roughly the size of my head.  That's what I'm looking for.  I come here once a week at least.  I've got lots of little punch-holes in my frequent-slice-eater card.

And now I'm going to share a little secret with you Yelp-readers: come to Escape From New York Pizza for lunch on Wednesdays.  Why, you ask?  Because that's the day they serve their crowning achievement: the meatball slice.  I will go out on a limb and say that their meatball slice is the finest slice of pizza to be found in San Francisco, beating even the mighty Za.  Really.  Meatball slices rule.

The only knock against Escape From NY is that it closes way too early.  If I'm working late (like I ever leave work before 7pm anyway) and I want a slice, I'm hosed!  Escape From NY closes at 7, and even if I'm in an enterprising mood and wander out there at 6, all that's left are the shriveled, dried up, hours-old remainders of lunchtime glory.

So this is primarily a lunch spot, no doubt about it.  Also, when they are open, they'll deliver all over the FiDi, which means that when I hold a lunch meeting, people actually come because they know it'll be full of lip-smacking meatball-pizza goodness.

Mmm.  Meatballs.
author: Marco C.

description:
Pizza is one of my favorite foods and Escape is doing a pretty good job. Of course if you can get a slice fresh from the oven, it is almost perfect. I usually get pepperoni or the combination (onions, pepperoni, sausage, green peppers). They do New York style, hand-tossed pies. 

We also call in orders for the office. They deliver, take orders at the last minute, and arrive promptly. Highly recommended.
author: Mel C.

description:
As a pizza joint I would give it zero stars.  I find their pizza dry, cold, and overpriced.  However, after we got off work yesterday, seeing as it was so nice out, my boyfriend and I wanted to go get a couple beers somewhere and sit outside.  We decided to walk up Bush and see how packed the Irish Bank was.  As we passed Escape From New York, we saw a bunch of tables outside with some people sitting enjoying a beer and/or slice of pizza.  There were a few free tables and not wanting to get to Irish Bank and find it packed, we decided to just sit down right there.  We were happy that we would be able to get a table outside.  We were even happier when we saw it was happy hour and beers were only $2!  Where in the financial district is there a $2 beer happy hour?  We were so stoked and ended up sitting at our little table enjoying the warm weather and watching the world go by for an hour!  

We will DEFINITELY be going back when it's warm and we actually want to be able to get a table outside.  Six beers and an hour at a table outside in the financial district for only $15?  What's not to love?  Just don't get their pizza.
author: Jen S.

description:
Comes close to a New York slice. The crust was perfect and the cheese was great. The sauce did leave a little to be desired though. And the fact that I spent $3.50 on a slice was a litte disappointing, but it is in the heart of the Financial District, so I was expecting it...

Update: Finally tried the Potato Pesto Pizza. It was actually really good. I still prefer the red sauce over the pesto, but this unique pizza is worth a try. There is tons of garlic and the potatos have lots of pepper to give it even more flavor.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Good pizza! Yum!
I've tried the chicken & spinach slice and the pesto & potato slice. I love the pesto & potato slice! It's filling and delicious! It also has cloves of roasted garlic, mmm. The chicken & spinach is pretty good, too. $4 flat for each slice, but they do have good deals for lunch time combos and what not.. like pizza slice, drink, salad or two slices and drink, etc.
Will come again when craving pizza during my lunch break :]
author: Jamie W.

description: Escape From NY on Bush now has the "Escape After Hours Bar" every Thurs through Saturday from 6 - 11.  They now have a few GOOD beers on tap, nice affordable glasses of wine, their same yummy slices, and an additional yummy bar bites type menu.  We just went last Friday for a slice and some beers... and KARAOKE.  It was TOOO FUNNY.  The host, Glenny Kravitz, is GREAT!!  He even sings backup vocals and harmonies on some songs!  We had a blast.  And it wasn't crowded, but pleasantly full, so we all had a few turns to sing.
author: shannon a.

description:
Nothing to rave home about.  I come by here if (1) I'm really craving a slice of Hawaiian pizza & (2) if I'm being really lazy (it's right next door to my office).

The servers appear to be really disgruntled the majority of the time, & half the time they're out of the type of pizza you want.  It is one of the cheapest places in FiDi to grab lunch though, so I can't complain too much.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I haven't actually been here yet, but I've had some co-workers bring me back sandwiches from here.  The meatball sub was one of the best I've ever had.  The italian sausage sandwich did not disappoint either.

I can't wait to try the pizza.
author: James W.

description: WOW...this is a review of my first visit to EFNYP.  I had a slice of potato and a slice of cheese and they were both delicious.  Total came out to about $8.  A little pricy for pizza by the slice BUT the slices were huge.  I will be back!
author: Huy T.

description: I went there for lunch today.  It's good..especially I got a buy one get one free coupon.  The slice is HUUUUGE...more like two slices...it covers my whole face. yea..
author: Moko R.

description: mmm, my second favorite place to eat pizza in the city. i come here all the time because it's a) delicious and b) cheap. potato? roasted garlic? pesto? all awesome. combined on a pizza? amazing. add a fresh crisp trumer pils and you've got the dinner of champions my friend.
author: Molly E.

description: Made a big order on short notice here and the delivery was on time.  Everyone loved the pizza.
author: Daria G.

description: Slightly overpriced but I really do enjoy their pepperoni pizza with some ranch sauce on the side.
author: vishal k.

description: These guys ALWAYS turn up on time with hot Pizza. Today I ordered for my office but the online order had it for delivery ASAP yet I thought I had selected the next day at 4pm. The delivery guy called in an they were really kind to take the pizzas back and deliver a fresh lot the next day. Awesome customer service. A lesson though, if you order online be sure to double check your order before you submit to make sure that you ordered it for the right time. Other than that the online system works a treat!!!!
author: Alice L.

description: I feel like pizza tonight like pizza tonight.  This place is like catching Die Hard on FX... yes you know the movie inside and out but if you happen upon it you know it's worth beering up and kicking back.  I can dine inside or out as suits my pleasure and roll my freshly-stamped card while viewing the lunch parade amble this way 'n that on their way in service to the King.  I being me prefer to stretch back and ponder the wisps of fog reaching for skyscrapers coyly dancing out of their frisky, tenuous reach, and enjoy my lunch minutes frozen within the hour of time appointed;  these moments are mine and I won't be heckled by the productivity peanut gallery or angry bee-buzzing blackberries.  This is my Escape and I shall not be deterred.  Hail New York.
author: Jim W.

description: Not too bad.  The crust was good enough for a NYC replica, although the sauce didn't quite have the flavor I was hoping for.  Regardless, the toppings were sufficient and I find that Escape From NY is a fine place to pick up a couple of slices.
author: Ben G.

description: Tasty cheap huge slices of plain crispy thin-crust pizza. If you're looking for a huge selection of schmancy duck, broccoli, clam, barbecue chicken pesto pizza, this is not the place to go. If you are just looking for pepperoni and other basics, you are at the right place.
author: Rob T.

description: Pretty good slice.  I love NY style thin crust.  Its especially tough to find in SF where places make pizza too fancy...   I just want aregular slice...this place has a few posh pizzas but cant go wrong with cheese or combo!
author: Naji E.

description: on 4pm-6pm weekdays, cheese and pepperoni pizza slices for $2.50. a solid deal after working 9-530, with plenty of indoor and outdoor seating. and they fact that they have monday night football ready when i arrive is icing on the ca-- eeerrm, the best topping you can umm... yeah
author: Ethan L.

description:
you really escaped from new york? bull honky! you taste more like jerzee. shame on me for falling for your name. you're a fraud. go back to jerzee. gosh, i'm so mean sometimes.

one additional star for the friendly staff. see, i'm nice.
author: frisco j.

description: Really close to my office -- well, a block away. Good for a slice, and the small spinach salad with sundried tomatoes and pinenuts is unexpectedly decent. It's a good, quick lunch option. And the goth girl with the bleached blonde hair, black Converse, and the subdued Siouxsie Sioux makeup reminds of me people I used to hang out with in high school.
author: Tara M.

description: Good budget lunchtime fare, and probably my current favorite slice in the area (though I have yet to try the newly opened Pizza Orgasmica location).  The high turnover at lunch means the slices are pretty fresh, and I happen to love their tomato sauce.  You can get 2 slices of pepperoni and a soda for six bucks, which is a little high for pizza, but cheap for the FiDi.  It's also amusing watching middle aged guys in business suits chat up the high school girls who work there on their summer breaks.  Get there just before noon on a sunny day if you want to enjoy the outdoor seating, it goes fast.
author: Steve G.

description: Sometimes I walk up to this place for lunch. The pizza is good, but not as good as some of their other locations. Still the outdoor seating is nice on a warm day.
author: Jordan M.

description: Very average pizza.  Lots of different, interesting looking slices, but almost all needed reheating.  For a lunch time slice or two, I'd much rather head to Cafe Vivoli a few blocks away.
author: Leon R.

description: Decent pizza, but nothing to write home about. I feel like this city is saturated with pizza options and this just doesn't compete. I've had the cheese, pepperoni, and big meat combo slices before, all of which were fine, if a little chewy... just definitely nothing spectacular. It's an okay lunch option if you work in the area or need a quick bite, but I'm honestly always a little underwhelmed when I stop by. After giving it a few shots, I'm unfortunately going to have to give up on this one... Next time I'm desperate for an easy snack and Bistro Burger is discouragingly crowded, I'll be hitting up What's Up Dog across the alley, with my head up high and zero regrets.
author: G. J.

description: I've lamented the fact there are no good pizza joints down here.  This is the best I've come across.  Not amazing, but perfect to satisfy that fix.
author: Denise C.

description:
for my money, this is the best pizza in san francisco. i know, i know, there's (probably) pizza in new york that's 10x better, but we're not in ny. and i want something to look forward to, pizza-wise. for now, give me a slice of mushroom and "you say potato" and i'm happy.

completely unrelated, does anyone else think that lily allen is the coolest female recording artist since blondie/debbie harry? yeah.
author: vincent m.

description: After reading all the great reviews on Yelp, I decided to try the financial district location for lunch...and to try the potato pesto.  I thought it was delicious, a little pricey but the slice was pretty huge and I was pleasantly full after eating it.  Definitely can't wait to go back.  I like the seating area too, it's a nice place to just sit inside and read and enjoy your lunch.
author: Preeti U.

description: It's a life saver for that once in awhile craving or late night project that catches you off-guard.
author: K W.

description: tasty pizza but man, two slices for $8. i know this is the city but jeez...i can get a whole pizza at costco for 10 bucks.
author: Greg H.

description: YOU SAY POTATO, best pesto and potato pizza i've had in town. delivery to all of fidi makes it very convenient to order in. use to work a block from this place but moved into soma and we still order from this place everytime.
author: Patrick M.

description: It's the best pizza I've had in this city so far...yes, a little pricey but they always have a coupon in SFWeekly so I never buy a slice without it.  The potato-pesto and the Hawaiian are my personal favourites.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Nice and hot, just had them delivered to the office a block away. since Im originally from Queen NY, this can not compare to the real NY pizza, but I'll still eat it.
author: Daniel W.

description: The pizza here is soooooo yummy!  They also have a great slice of pizza, salad, soda combo for lunch.  Every slice I've had is super yummy and the crust is delicious.  I would totally recommend for a quick lunch away from the office!
author: MilHouse D.

description:
The poetry and gorilla hanging on the walls make this an interesting place to grab a quick bite.  This is thin, crispy crust pizza...none of that thick or limp junk.

Escape from New York has become my standard Monday pizza lunch.  I always order the same things if they're available.  I have a Hawaiian heated up for lunchtime and I take a slice of potato garlic pesto back with me to the office to eat before salsa or yoga class in the evening.  For some reason, I think the potato pizza tastes best when cold.
.  
There is also a $2.50 happy hour for pizza and beer that I've been meaning to try.
author: Krystle C.

description: potato pesto pizza is super-greasy & more importantly, super-bland which one would think hard to achieve, given the whole cloves of garlic....won't be back
author: Adrienne G.

description: Its good east coast style pizza period.
author: Joel M.

description: I'd give them 3 and 1/2 if I could.  Ingredients are fresh and the pizza is pretty good.  It's a bit on the thick side for a ny pizza and the crust isn't firm enough, but the flavors are all there, so that's nice.  My office likes to order the Potato, Pesto and Garlic pizza and it's pretty good.  Better than most pizza around SF, unless you go to some of the nicer restaurants for dine in.
author: Ron T.

description: i love this pizza ... great meatballs . love the sausage they use, its like no other pizza place. Everyone that works at this location seems to be really cool .. Ive been inside the place a few times , lost of art students that live near by work there .. pretty down to earth,  no bullshit ... if your downtown and want a slice ... stop in .. you will not be disappointed.
author: dale b.

description: I swear the kids who work here are heroine-addicts or something, but I'm trying not to pass judgement. After I ordered my pizza one of them just stood there and did nothing while I waited 10 minutes for a slice of pepperoni that wasn't coming. I finally asked what the hold up was and he stood there clueless. Well, they served up my pizza 15 minutes after ordering it. The pizza was excellent, but they lose a lot of points for their service.
author: Jonathan B.

description: I am a fan.  Their potato garlic is a cryptonite for me.  Well, I guess it is for everyone around me after I eat it, too.  This place will kill ya if you eat there everyday but man that is some great pie.  Thin crust not too crunchy...good selection of pie, good selection of beers, good eye candy a lot of the time.  One of my favorite spots to re-fill the tank with bad empty calories and relax for a bit.  LOVE IT!
author: B G.

description: Really good pizza. The Teriyaki chicken pizza and the Sliced Potato and Pesto pizza are very very savory. The crust is great and the slices are filling. Service is fast and friendly. Awesome pizza joint.
author: Marco M.

description: Blondies-sized slices with East Coast bubbly-on-the-bottom crisp crust. You will play Fidi prices here, though.  I paid $8 for two slices of combo the other day.  Yikes!
author: Nathan W.

description:
last week my boss asked me what kinda pizza i wanted for lunch - uhh mushroom?  then he comes back and said oh u noe this place has great soups too, did u want any? what kind? gumbo. gumbo??? i LOVEEEEEE gumbo.  i love gumbo like i was born in the south i love gumbo.  

then my food awaits me at my desk - wow.  the pizza was awesome, the gumbo was great (yeah right like u can f*ck up gumbo for me).  where did you get this at i ask? earlier he said something about "new york... pizza" then he said again "oh that deli down the street.. lee's" wait what?? fear of sounding slow i didnt ask for clarification.

so i did some yelping and yelped "new york pizza" in the financial district...  and this came up, so i came here for lunch today and gross am i disappointed! the sauce on the pizza is just wrong and super strong... and for like the last 2 inches of my pizza there are no mushrooms on it.  this cant be the place where the pizza came from last week.  ANNNNNND they didnt serve gumbo.  what a b*tch.  

ok ok... came back to my computer and yelped "gumbo" in the financial district and lee's deli came up.. guess where im having lunch tomorrow??? that's right.....  but where did the pizza come from??? and the mystery continues...
author: Tina L.

description: Once again, it's the You Say Potato pizza FTW. While this branch does close at an ungodly 6:30pm, the do take plastic and there's booze unlike the one on Haight. And I can get here very quickly from the Mission: the BART exit at Monty station has a tunnel that leads to Monty street and then one more block to Bush. I'm amazed (and scared) at how fast I got here to get some slices to take home...
author: Maximillian M.

description: I enjoy the occasional lunch slice from this location.  Service is very fast and friendly.  The pizza gets the job done and is a cheap, filling lunch option in FiDi compared to the $10 sandwiches in the area.  I have noticed the slices are often not warmed up quite enough.  I'll keep going back, though.  At least until the food makes me ill.
author: Daryl E.

description: I am a fan of the big meat combo. And they finally deliver on weekends!
author: Yeechang L.

description: Good enough pizza.  It's simple, not cheap but not too expensive either.  I prefer Escape from NY over Orgasmica for lunch because of the speedy service and abundant inside and outside seating.  Neither place has very friendly service; the prices are similar; and I say the pizza itself is edible at both places, although I will give Escape from NY a slight edge.  If you're looking for a quick bite during lunch, I nod for Escape from NY.
author: Daniel L.

description: If you work in the Financial District, this is a good place to go for a quick bite. Order the Pesto-Potato slice and grab a Cricket Cola: You got yourself a lunch. Eat it and get back to work. There are clients who need you!!! I will go back...the next time I need a 15 minute lunch and Jamba Juice just won't do for the fourth time this week!
author: Johnny O.

description: Let's face it, it's downtown pizza. Overpriced and inconsistent. That being said, it's still the best in the area, and has the saving graces of a) 4-6 p.m.happy hour (which used to be 3-6, but now I'm grousing), and b) pretty danged good subs. And by subs, I'm taking the throw one or two of our ingredients onto a semi-stale bun and pour sauce, add cheese, grill. Basically, how any good italian style sub should be.
author: Geof M.

description:
I was here a long time ago and haven't come back ever since, so I can't remember that much to give the details, but I do remember that I didn't like it.  The dough part was so thin, it was hard and hard to chew.  The pizza itself wasn't that good.  But regarding service and sanitation, it's pretty good.

*update: i didn't notice the address above at first, but my review applies to the "Escape from New York Pizza" on Castro & 18th Street
author: Karen C.

description: It's Pizza!  The crust is good, the price is good, the taste is good.  Overall is a great place to grab a quick bite to eat for lunch.
author: Laura C.

description: okay pizza but nothing to rave about... unfortunately it is probably the best option in the financial district.  i usually go with their ham and pineapple or the spinach/feta/sun-dried tomato... think there's chokes on there too.  anyway, a bit pricey for a slice of pizza but they can get away with it in the financial district.  the salad/slice combo is a decent option.
author: Yvette H.

description: yummy pizza.  makes for a cheap lunch which is hard to come by in the Financial District (see review of mixt greens)  and better than some other pizza choices nearby (see review of Enzos).  Nice area outside to sit, not like i would know, because i always run back to work and eat at my desk....god i am lame!
author: Kari P.

description: i love all-you-can-eat pizza and poetry nights... go for the pizza, run from the poetry. pizza's always good, and the slices are just right. mmm, pesto and potato!
author: Bee H.

description: Yummy sandwiches as well as pizza! The chicken parm sandwich rocks! Go get it for lunch
author: Samantha G.

description: Some of their other locations are good, and maybe I went at an off time (4:30 pm), but the slice I got was VERY unsatisfying.  Blondie's is way better.
author: Jake M.

description: Best pizza in town.  Try the pesto!  You can go in and order by the slice, pick up, or have it delivered.
author: Kristen R.

description: yeah it's just pizza.  the one on Haight st is better, that is for sure.  just finished eating a pepperoni pie.  i think their strength lies in the slice.  not really the whole pie.  the dough is uneven sauce distributed uneven, eh but it's pizza.  what are you going to do.  i think next time I'll order amici's.
author: Anthony Y.
